fol.51r
May it please yo
r
good L: yest
r
night I rxd 2 l
re
s from you, to wit of
e
19 & 24 of M
r
che, w
ch
were both by
S
r
Francis Vere
, who went out of
Zeland
directly to
e campe, & sent mee these l
re
s fr
o
Middelborough
hither, & some what in writing astouching his erand, differring
e rest till
his coming to
e Hage. I have had some l
re
s in like manner from
my
L. Treasorer
, in w
ch
e cause of his coming ys but told mee in g
na
l
& for furder
ticularities I am referred to his report. And this is
e
occasyon
t
before I am acquainted w
th
S
r
Francis instructions, &
t
inwardly and fully I cannot as I would & as yo
r
L: doth desire, deliver
my opinion conc
r
ning
e successe. Nev
r
theles becaus I am uncertaine
when to speake w
th
him heere, & I finde at this p
nt
an opportunity
to write, I will shewe yo
r
L: in a worde my private conceate
upon
t
w
ch
I knowe, as touching this message: And if his
comming to
e
Count
hath some furder secret meaning for
e
s
vice of
her
Ma
ty
when I know
e depth of yt, I hope to write to better
purpose. As yet I am enformed
t
for
e matter of his
charge, it doth but tend to this effect, To encourage Count
Maurice, to be
[siege]
e Towne of
Donkerk,
& to make her Ma
ties
excuse, for no
[.]
ing any ayde. To signify to yo
r
L: what I
think in that beh
[alf it]
would require a declaration, of that w
ch
heertofore I have writen in
at matt
r
to my L. Th
re
r. And for
that I am not sure,
t
it came to yo
r
L. knowledge, I have
sent heerinclosed
e coppie of
t
l
re
: Wheruppon to goe forwarde
it may please you to und
r
stand, that according to
t
w
ch
was the
intended, both heere & in
Frise
.
Count William
is de
ted wth 15 ensignes
of Frysons w
ch
amount unto
e nomb
r
of toward
3000 to erect a
fort uppon
e passage between
Groeninghen
&
Linghen,
at a place
called
Wedde
about 6 Dutch miles southwest from Groeninghen.
It is also said that as many in nomb
r
of
e Enemy are m
r
ched
thitherward w
th
diligence, to defeate him of his purpose. If
e
Count th
r
uppon shal be forced to retire hee shall also be constrained
to parte his men in garrison for
e defence of his townes & places
wh
r
by hee may be able to send a 1000 or 1500 to
e enterprise of
Donkerke or oth
r
exploit in these quarters. But if he have
e
time to fortify
e passage before
e arrival of
e enemy, wherof
wee are in dout, it is thowght that of necessity he must keepe his
strength together for defence of his forte, unles
e Enemy drawe backe.
fol.51v
Count Maurice as yo
r
L. hath heard is engaged heere greatly [.]
of
Geertrud
e
berge:
wher his approches were almost finished as [.]
daies ago, but by reason of a spring tide, & a Northwest winde, [.]
waters th
r
about were raised so highe, & came so suddainely upon the [.]
as divers of
e souldiers were drowned in
e trenches, &
e chiefest [.]
these works were cleane ov
r
thr
owen. By reason of
e time w
ch
[.]
force they must spend, to recover this losse, & because yt should [.]
that those w
th
in
t
towne are better stoared of powder & of every [.]
els, then Count Maurice made account, yt is like to prove a [.]
siege, then it seemed at first we had cause to expect. Wh[.]
to come to that w
ch
yo
r
L: would knowe I suppose by all app[.]
that therafter as Count Maurice doth speede in this attempt, they [.]
afterward
happen to consult about Donkerk. And yet to p[.]
that they will in good time be maisters of Geertrudenberg, [.]
not well comp
r
hend how sufficient they wil bee to beset
e to[wne of]
Donkerk, except they may be holpen w
th
some power of her Ma[jesty]
For unles they be assisted w
th
some thousand out of Friseland, [.]
e rest that
e state is able to sp
[.]
not passing 6000 foo[te and]
1500 horse, of w
ch
they must leav
[e .]
Gertrudenberg bee taken
there in garrison. The
[.]
then consydered, & how [.]
carefully the Enemy will d[o their]] utmost endevo
r
for p
r
ser[ving]
of that towne, as by w
ch
they have bin & are very singul
r
ly [.]
I can see but litell likelihoode of
e matter going forwarde. [.]
I think wil be
e speeches of Count Maurice to S
r
Francis. f[.]
maner I am c
r
taine that (to hope upon
e best) he shall [.]
no other from him, then a doutfull kinde of answere: as [.]
not in his power to make any other: the matt
r
depending [.]
States resolution w
ch
are neither now together, nor like to [be]
shortly for ought that can be learned. Al this notw
th
s[tanding]
I am
tly of opinion, if theyr attempt
fall out happely to[.]
& in Frise, but chiefly this in
Holland,
the desire they will [.]
to prosecute
e victory, &
e spetiall affection, that
ey be[.]
S
r
Francis Vere, will cause them to growe to some termes w
th
h[er]
Ma
ty
for entertaining an Englishe regiment at theyr owne charge [.]
to be conducted by S
r
Francis, if so be that her Ma
ty
will but
ayde them a litell. And this is all of that matter, that I
can signify or conjecture, til I talke w
th
S
r
Francis, and though
it bee not to suche purpose, as yo
r
L: would have it, yet I repose so grea[t]
a truste in yo
r
honorable kindenes, as for all kinde of errors of this
quality. I will ever live in hope to have a
don of course
&c.
